div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7237] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JULY 11, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: CONSCRIPTION.
div.p: Lord Roberts’s outspoken utterances in the House of Lords yesterday during the debate on National Defence will do much to hasten the approach of the day when compulsory service will have to be adopted as the only solution of the problem of the defence of our world-wide empire. Compulsory service must sooner or later become inevitable. The Army, it is stated, is in the melting-pot—a pot that has received such a stirring and shaking recently as to have had much of its contents upset ; and from what remains it can scarcely be hoped to mould that ideal, though limited, Army, which we are told the Empire needs. Some new weighty metal will have to be added to strengthen and steady the seething mass, and must either be bought dearly, or demanded, free. One thing alone can make some sort of universal service a necessity—lack of recruits, or even, with our large foreign garrison, lack of suitable recruits. Men are now being enlisted for nine years with the colours, and, so far, recruiting under this order has been satisfactory : in fact, recently the War Office complacently published figures to prove this, and to show that the decrease in numbers was of small moment—was a necessity, in fact, to effect a saving in the Estimates, and possessed advantage in that each man now enlisted is available for foreign service, whereas a small percentage only of the short service men became eligible by extending their service. Apart from the fact that the question of the extension of short service men was a misleading comparison, seeing that for some time past the War Office has, of necessity, been despatching drafts to India composed wholly of three-years men who had not extended, the question arises:—If, during the winter and a period of exceptional distress the recruiting returns (under the long service system) showed a decided decrease, what will happen now when a plenitude of labour, and summer, which so greatly modifies the need for housing, clothing, and food, have returned ? At such a time the Militia generally provides a sufficiently convenient refuge for those in want of temporary subsistence. To subsequent intending recruits the disadvantage of service that will most weigh with them, after the loss of freedom, will be service in India. Nothing contributed more to the success of the short service system—from the recruiting point of view only—than the tact that the recruit did not anticipate service abroad in his three years. Nothing will exercise a greater deterrent effect on recruiting than the prospect of serving eight and a half years in the tropics.

Lack of prospect of employment on return to civil life is not the chief recruiting deterrent to the extent supposed. The indigent recruit, in common with the deliberate soldier, does not give this remote possibility too deep thought. Very few soldiers give their future prospects consideration till towards the end of their service, and often not until they finally go on furlough pending discharge. It may have a small deterrent effect through the agency of those ex-soldiers who have been unsuccessful in their quest for employment but their testimony is not so convincing as the maladvertisement of service abroad by ex soldiers who have been detained beyond their time in India, are ruined in health, and thereby unable to earn a living.

Will the Government revert to short service when the long service system has resulted in that decrease of establishment (with too great precipitation, perhaps; which we were told was desirable ? Every experienced military officer will pray not; since our recent experience has unquestionably proved to what a great extent such a system resulted in a deterioration in quality of personnel. But would the system meet with its former success ? Scarcely, for these reasons : there is not now the stimulus of the South African War ; and the great prudent recruiting class have learnt that, first, without extension of service they are ineligible for service pay, and then only after two years’ service, subject to restrictions ; secondly, that, in some measure to make up for their short stay in the Army, they have to undergo extra drills, and are not given staff billets ; and, finally, that short service has been proved to be no guarantee against foreign service. There is an increased reluctance on the part of the better-class section of the community to enlist, due, perhaps, to the general improvement in wages, and increased love of independence, and a progressive standard of comfort and domesticity—the last two notable absentees from Army life—and to the fact that, owing to the spread of education, the Army no longer offers an attractive career of quick promotion to the moderately educated. The corps—such as the Royal Engineers and Army Service Corps—which offer a congenial prospect to skilled workers, clerks, are always well filled ; but the infantry and cavalry gain precious few of these eminently desirable men.

However limited our army is to be, a very large force (about 112,000, now that the Egyptian garrison has been reduced) is needed for garrisoning India and the Colonies, and must be maintained by drafts from the home Army ; whilst, as pointed out by Lord Roberts, Russia’s encroachment on the Indian frontier places us in a position something similar to the great European military Powers. When the recruits fail to come, the Army at home will be depleted owing to the provision of drafts for the foreign battalions, to vanishing point. What, then, will remain for defence at home in the event of threatened invasion? A skeleton regular Army, with an increased obligation to provide drafts for abroad ; a rapidly dwindling Volunteer force of 250,000, which is now threatened by a farther reduction of 50,000 ; the Militia of 118,000 ; and the Reserve of 70,000, the greater part of whom would be required for the battalions abroad. The quality of this Reserve, formed so largely of short service men, is incomparably below that which strengthened our Army daring the South African War. After the inadequate tempering of the material in a fitful three years, what will be the value of the article after eight or nine years’ disuse ? The rearmament of the artillery, and issue to the infantry of the new short rifle will not render this addition of numbers (scarcely strength) the more effective. The available force, therefore, would scarcely suffice for the formation of adequate offensive corps. And in that case the defence of towns and villages must rest with the citizen. How far are we prepared for this contingency ? The Boer system of military service was, within certain limits, ideal ; and something of the sort was attempted on a small scale in Cape Colony by the formation of Town Guards under self-elected officers. And during the invasion of Cape Colony by the Boers excellent service was rendered by these extempore soldiers. Some such system will eventually have to be established in England. If all able-bodied men in each village or district were enrolled, electing their own officers from among them, and divided into established sections for the defence of certain points, a backbone of undoubted rigidity and strength would be added to the defence of the country. An initial training of some fourteen days or so under competent regular instructors, and a subsequent three days annually, with the liberal use of rifle ranges, should result in a useful irregular body at least capable of adequately defending their own homes, thus enabling the standing force to be employed elsewhere. The provision of ranges is, of course, the chief difficulty ; but miniature ranges, on which the ordinary .303 ball ammunition can be used, have been constructed at Hythe and Sheffield, and have proved of great practical utility. Thus only might distasteful conscription be obviated.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect. Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head:
NATIONAL DEFENCE.
A DEBATE IN UPPER HOUSE.
MR. BALFOUR CRITICISED.
LORD “BOBS” AND CONSCRIPTION.

div.p: During the debate on National Defence in the House of Lords Mr. Balfour’s statement of the 11th of May was severely criticised. Lord Roberts said that the lessons of the South African war were already^ forgotten. He had no hesitation in saying that the army is as absolutely unfitted and unprepared for war now as it was then. The nation must choose between conscription and universal training. (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE “ENTENTE CORDIALE.”
BRITISH FLEET AT BREST.

div.p: The preparations for the reception of the British fleet, which will arrive to-day, have just been completed. The rejoicings promise to constitute a record in international naval courtesies. The programme of official and private festivities is so huge that there will hardly be an hour during the whole week that will not be accounted for.
There are evidences on every side that the visit is most popular. (Reuter.)
The British squadron has arrived in order to assist at the fêtes given in its honor. Its arrival was cheered by those on shore. (Havas.)
The British fleet arrived this afternoon. There was a remarkable demonstration of welcome by immense crowds ashore and afloat.(R.)

Chamber of Deputies. — M. Rouvier announced that France has accepted the Morocco Conference and that Germany recognised French rights and interests. M. Rouvier’s words were greeted with unanimous applause. (Havas.)

M. Rouvier announced in the Chamber that France and Germany have agreed to an international conference on the lines mentioned yesterday. He stated that the missions at Fes will be recalled when the conference meets. Germany has not raised the question of the Anglo-French nor the Franco-Spanish agreements, which are not mentioned in the negotiations. (Reuter.)
The Socialist organ “Vorwaerts” has publishd M. Jaures's lecture textually. The tone is moderate and most friendly to Germany.
There is a notable warmth the reference to the Anglo-French entente, declaring that “we shall resist to our last breath any attempt to entangle us in hostile action with Great Britain.” (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE PEACE COMMISSION.
PLACE OF MEETING.

div.p: The peace plenipotentiaries will meet at Portsmouth in the State of New Hampshire. (Reuter.)
The Japanese loan has been issued.(R )
M. Bougouin, mentioned in despatches of the 10th of May, has been sentenced to 10 4 years’ hard labour, and the interpreter Maki to 8. (Reuter)

div.head:
CORRUPTION IN WASHINGTON.
LEAKAGE OF COTTON REPORTS.

div.p: Owing to constant complaints of the leakage of cotton reports to brokers, the Government has instituted an enquiry which has resulted in the dismissal of the leading statistician at the Department of Agriculture. (Reuter)
It is not believed that it will be possible to raise the submarine before some days. The Minister of Marine has arrived and has gone for a long submarine trip in a vessel of the same type. (Reuter.)
The disorders mentioned on the 8th inst. have been settled. A new Crew has been embarked. (Reuter.)

div.head: Rains
div.p: in the Kassala to be late.

div.head: The New Anti-Rabic Institute,
div.p: it is expected, will be completed by the end of the year.

div.head: Agricultural Shows
div.p: are to be held in the Fayoum and at Mansourah in September and October next.

div.head: Little Girl Drowned.
div.p: A child, named Um el Saâd, four years of age, was accidentally drowned in a masraf at Boghos Pasha’s ezbeh.

div.head: Stray and Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in the Saida Zeynab quarter of Cairo during the night of Wednesday and at daylight on Thurs day will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Defrauding the Revenue.
div.p: A man named Antonio Carabot was arrested yesterday with a quantity of silk thread in his possession which he was attempting to smuggle.

div.head: P. W. D.
div.p: Sir Wm. Garstin’s Report for 1904 on the Public Works Department is in the hands of the printer, and will be published in October next.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: 10 vessels passed through the Canal on the 7th inst., 8 of which were British, 1 French, 1 German. The day’s receipts were frs. 293,573.11, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 2,126,168.89.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday’s bulletin records a fatal case at Alexandria, the victim being a native fisherman who was found dead at his house at Khattabieh. A fatal case is reported from Ashmoun, a death from Damanhour, and a recovery from Menouf.

div.head: Theatre Regulations.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has sent the new regulations for theatres to the Ministry of Justice in order to be submitted to the Mixed Court of Appeal for its approval, which cannot be given till after the vacation.

div.head: Mosque for Paris
div.p: M. Lion Lambeir, a French merchant, has decided to construct a mosque in Paris, and has asked the French Government to grant him a site for the purpose. A fatwa has been signed by the rector of El Azhar University approving the project.

div.head: An Absconding Clerk.
div.p: M. Leonardo Golisti, advocate, has informed the Attarin police that his clerk, named Abdulla Hozalli el Shami, to whom he had entrusted a cheque of £50 in order to pay costs in a law case at the Mixed Tribunal, has absconded with the money. _

div.head: Another Case of Embezzlement.
div.p: The Attarin police have also received notice from M. George Maisokis, director of the Kafr-el-Zayat Cotton Co., that a man named Ahmed Mursi had cashed a cheque for L.E. 61 with the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, and had absconded with the money. _

div.head: Suspicious Death.
div.p: The Alexandria Gouvernorat has been informed by the Minet el Bassal police that a man named Moh. El Said Rizk, who had died in his house, was found, by the medical officer who was called in, to have a severe wound on the forehead. His relatives, when questioned, said that the deceased suffered from hysteria, which caused the injuries that resulted in his death.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Earl of Cromer was one of the guests at a dinner party given on Saturday week by the Prince of Wales in honor of Prince Arisugawa of Japan.
Sir Wm. Garstin left Cairo this morning for Port Said, where he will embark on the P.& O. S.S. Britannia.
Mr. E. B. Gould I.S.O., H.B.M’s Consul- General at Alexandria, and Mrs. Gould are leaving for Europe on Saturday next.
Mr. A. D. Alban, H.B.M’s Consul in Cairo, and Mrs. Alban leave for Europe by the French steamer on Friday.

Two marriages of local interest take place to-morrow in London, one at St. Peter’s, Eaton square, where Major D. K. E. Hall, A.S.C. (Egyptian Army), will be married to Mrs. R. Howe Davis, of Sandy Hill, Crafton, California; and the other at St. George’s, Hanover square, where Captain C. W. Maclean, Lancashire Fusiliers, will wed Miss Gladys Royle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Royle, of Ghezifeh, Cairo. On the 18th, Mr. Horace Rumbold, second secretary at the British Agency, eldest son of Sir Horace Rumbold, formerly British Ambassador to Austria, marries Miss Etheldred Fane, daughter of the late Sir Edmund Fane, British Minister to Denmark.
Halil Hamada Pasha, Director of Customs at Alexandria, who has been staying at Constantinople, has now left for Western Europe.
We are glad to hear that Mr. G. de Beaupuis, manager of the Banco di Roma in Alex andria, is making very satisfactory progress and hopes to return to Egypt at the end of the month.
Mr. H. W. Tite, chief inspector of the International Sleeping Car Company, arrived in Cairo yesterday from Paris. He will shortly leave for Cyprus, where Mrs. Tite is passing the summer.

div.head:
STATE RAILWAY CONTRACTS.
AN OFFICIAL DEMENTI.
div.p: Statements having appeared in certain newspapers to the effect that the German Diplomatic Agent in Egypt had protested against an alleged change in the system of placing railway contracts by international competition, we are authorised to state that the German Diplomatic Agent has informed the authorities concerned that no complaints whatever have been made to him.

We are further authorised to state that no change of policy has occurred, but exceptions to the rule are now, as they were formerly, committed when it is clearly to the public’s advantage to dispense with competition, and owing to the very rapid increase of traffic within the last twelve months, the number of exceptional eases which have recently occurred has been large. This has no doubt given rise to the rumours alluded to. w

The exceptional cases mentioned have as a rule taken the form of giving orders in extension of their contract to firms who have been successful in previous competitions, in order to avoid the delay necessitated by a fresh competition.

div.head: THE GRAND MUFTI.
div.p: We regret to learn this morning that the condition of the Grand Mufti has taken another turn for the worse. Little hope is now entertained of his recovery.

div.head: ESNEH BARRAGE.
div.p: The Public Works Department expect to commence the construction of the Esneh Barrage next year. Tenders will be invited in October next.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
div.p: The following telegram has been received from Mr. Price of New York by Mr. G. L. Sursock:— “Market possibly entitled to some reaction, but doubtful ; it is on its certain way to twelve cents in my opinion.”

div.head: DEAR CEREALS.
div.p: The country is suffering considerably this year from the high price of cereals. Durrah and beans, which form the principal ingredient in the diet of the fellah, have reached the price of P,T. 9 to 10 per keila. In spite of the excellent barley crop in the Mariout district, for which the abundant rains of last winter are responsible, the price of barley has risen to from P.T. 63 to 65 per ardeb, against an average of P.T. 45 per ardeb in 1904, when the rain crop was to all intents and purposes non-existent The English and Con­tinental breweries have bought up a very large proportion of this year’s crop, and the barley from the rain belt is evidently in as high request among brewers as ever. The present price of these cereals makes the feeding of horses and cattle a very costly affair. The bersim is over and the poorer owners of cattle and horses are sometimes obliged to give their beasts half rations.

div.head: MORTGAGES IN EGYPT.
div.p: It is stated that the Land Bank of Egypt has announced that it will issue no further loans on mortgages till the end of September. This bank has already placed upwards of £1,300,000 on similar loans since its foundation six months ago. The other mortgage-banks are only accepting on an average about 5 per cent. of the transactions proposed. The natural result of this action on their part is the growth of a certain uneasiness among land-owners, who find great difficulty in obtaining the money required for the exploitation of their lands. The Agricultural Bank, of course, confines its operations to the small cultivator.

div.head: PORT OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: During the half-year ended June 30 the number of vessels of all nationalities which entered the port of Alexandria was 856, of which number 367 were British. Other nationalities were represented as follows: — Italian 92, Greek 81, Austrian 77, French 59, German 54, Ottoman 49, Russian 48, Belgian 12, Swedish 8, Norwegian 2, Spanish 2, American 2, Dutch 2, Danish 1.

Of the 367 vessels which flew the British flag it is interesting to note that 54 belonged to the Khedivial Mail Line, 48 to Bell’s Asia Minor Company, 40 to the Prince Line, 36 to the Ellerman Lines, 20 to the Moss Line, 12 to the Westcott and Lawrence Line, and 5 to the P. and O. Company. Of the 92 Italian steamers, 65 belonged to the Florio-Rubattino Company. 51 of the 59 French vessels belonged to the Messageries Maritimes, 68 of the 77 Austrian to the Austrian Lloyd Company, 30 of the German to the Deutsche Levantie Line and 23 to the Norddeutsoher Lloyd. During the six months four men-of-war (two British, one German, and one Italian) paid a visit to this port.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Scottish Prince arrived in Manchester from Alexandria on Saturday last.
The S.S. Avon (Ellerman Line) arrived at Liverpool from Alexandria on Tuesday.
The S.S. Bulgarian (Ellerman Line) will sail hence for Liverpool on Wednesday.

div.head:
BRITISH TRADE IN EGYPT.
MR. FREEMAN’S REPORT.
div.p: In his report on the trade of Alexandria for 1904 Mr. Vice-Consul Freeman remarks ;— The answer to the question why the United Kingdom is, or at any rate seems to be, gradually losing the largest share in respect of the total imports is perhaps to be found in the wonderfully prosperous condition of the country, in the greater attention that it consequently, attracts among Continental manufacturers and merchants, and in the keener desire aroused on their part to enter so tempting a market. The contributions of countries other than those specified in the table have more than doubled in the space of four years. Postal parcels and the various goods included under the heading of “Other imports” have likewise doubled in four years. The expansion is spread over all categories and almost all items, and the stock inquiry : “Where are there openings for British trade ?” can best be answered with the one word “everywhere.” But at the same time I can only repeat the stock advice to manufacturers, jointly or singly, to have agents on the spot and to send more travellers. As the representative of a group of British firms remarked to me, the native tastes may not change, the same class of goods may be in demand for years, but nevertheless local requirements should be studied at the outset, and regular, periodical visits are necessary to ensure a hold on the market. The agents at Alexandria of a British firm dealing in carpenters’ and blacksmiths’ tools and also in Sheffield goods in general wrote to this Consulate as follows:—“The difficulty with our principals arises from the fact that the native does not use the same tools as the British workman. Many modifications and additions have consequently to be made so as to adapt the tools to what is required on our markets. If it were a question of a few articles only, the difficulty could easily be overcome by sending home samples ; but as there are a thousand and probably more lines that have to be attended to you will easily understand how impossible it is for an agent who is neither a carpenter nor a blacksmith to give them all the particulars they want. We therefore suggested that they should send out either one of the partners in their firm or a competent traveller, who, with our help, might secure the first orders. What we have to complain of most in the firms at home is that, although our markets are invaded by an army of foreign travellers, they (the British firms) do not take the trouble or care to incur the expense of sending out competent men to see what others are doing. We may give you as an instance the case of Messrs.….…..whose turnover with us was very small until they decided to send out one of the partners of the firm. They are now doing many more thousands than they did hundreds.”

Another British commercial traveller told me that his quotation for certain goods was 18s. per cwt. (1l. 16s. per 100 kilos.) with three months’ credit, while the German quotation, thanks partly to the drawback in Germany, was 25 fr. (1l.) per 100 kilos., with six months’ credit. The British article was of course better, and some people preferred it, but it was not, as the priced would seem to show, worth nearly twice as much as the German article. With such competition as this to face, merchandise, however excellent in itself, can scarcely be left to speak for itself with any prospect of success. I hear of machinery being bought in the United Kingdom by German firms and sold at Alexandria more cheaply than if it were imported direct. Here again there is surely scope for the energies of a British traveller.

Inquiries of all kinds are received at this Consulate in ever increasing numbers, and it is becoming almost impossible to answer them all. The prospects and possibilities of this trade and of that trade, the restrictions and regulations to which they are subject, a description of the articles already in the market, —such inquiries cannot be usefully answered except after long and careful study of the conditions affecting each particular trade, and this study a Consul has no time to undertake.

div.head: FRENCH FETE.
div.p: Preparations for the celebration in Cairo of the French fête on Friday next are almost completed. A large and well-decorated triumphal arch has been erected at the Boulac entrance of the Esbekieh Gardens, and this will be illuminated on the night of the 14th. A wooden pavilion has been erected in the gardens for the official receptions and a stage has also b3en erected for a variety entertainment which will be given by the troupe of the “Nouveautés.” The gardens are gaily decorated with flags and promise to look most effective when lit up by the numerous Chinese lanterns and electric globes which are hung in every direction. The bands of the 2nd Royal lnniskilling Fusiliers and the Egyptian Cavalry will perform alternately throughout the evening, and there will also be a grand display of fireworks.

All entrances to the gardens except the Boulac one will be closed and this will be opened at 9 p.m. The officers of the Egyptian Army and the Army of Occupation have accepted the invitation of the committee to assist at the festivities.

div.head: BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER
div.p: BREMEN.
FEARS NO HONEST COMPETITION FOR QUALITY.
N.B. -- Inferior Brands now being offered to Managers of certain good circles.
Beware of evilly disposed competitors running down this very Superior Brand of Beer

div.head: FEVER ON THE INCREASE.
div.p: The weather is becoming more oppressive than ever, owing to the hot khamseen winds. Fever is daily on the increase, both among the natives and Europeans, especially among the railway people. The latest victim in hospital is Mr. W. H. Bailey, Inspector of Bridges, Suakin-Atbara Line, who is, however, progressing favorably towards recovery.

The following passengers are leaving by the S.S. Dakahlieh to-day, viz., Mr. Smart, chief storekeeper, Suakin Railway, who is being invalided home to England, Mr. Fulton and Mr. Finlay, also of the Suakin-Atbara Rail­ways, who are likewise returning to England invalided as unfit for Suakin.
Mr. Ward, chief engineer of the Sudan Government steamer Hawk, having resigned his appointment with the Sudan Government, also leaves to-day by the Dakahlieh.

Dr. Crispin, senior medical officer, Suakin Moudirieh, is also a passenger by the S.S. Dakahlieh. He is going on three months’ leave of absence, which he will spend in England. During the absence of Dr. Crispin, Dr. Ibrahim Effendy Fahmy will act as S.M.O.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST.
div.p: The report of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., submitted to the statutory meeting on the 6th instant, states that with a view to spreading the company’s investments over as wide a field as possible, the directors are acquiring a large building area in the heart of Cairo, and their agent-general in Egypt, Mr. Hooker, who has recently been to London to confer with the board, has just left for Egypt to complete the arrangements, subject to the titles of the property proving satisfactory. If this business is concluded the directors have no hesitation in saying that it will be a most satisfactory investment for the company. The directors are also on the point of completing the purchase of some very valuable building land in Alexandria which has been strongly recommended to them by their local advisers. The directors feel that when these transactions are concluded the shareholders will have a considerable interest in the heart of the two most important cities in Egypt—namely, Cairo and Alexandria, which cannot fail to give most satisfactory results. In view of the growing importance of the Egyptian Mining industry, the directors are supporting on favorable terms the issue of the Egyptian Gold and Emerald Company, Ltd. In this they are acting in conjunction with the United African Explorations, Ltd. The Egyptian Gold and Emerald Company, Ltd., is formed to acquire what appears to be one of the most important mineral concessions in Egypt. The concession comprises an area of some 3,000 square miles, and it is reported upon by responsible engineers as being rich in gold, silver, lead, copper and emerald mines. The directors have also before them various proposals, which are likely to materialise shortly, for the development of sound and profitable business in other directions. The Board have elected Mr. Charles H. Rigg as a director to represent his substantial financial interest in the company.
July 5 was fixed by the committee of the London Stock Exchange as a special settling day in Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, 200,000 shares of £1 each, 5s paid (Nos. 1 to 200,000).

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondants, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit—within certain necessary limits—free discussion.

div.head: CAIRO STREET NUISANCE.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—I should be greatly obliged if you would, through your columns, call the attention of the Cairo police to another street nuisance which exists. At most of the junctions of two streets cabstands exist, and the cabmen appear to think that they have a right to stand in such a manner that the passage of pedestrians is entirely obstructed. The cabmen naturally wish to look for fares along both roads, and draw up their cabs accordingly, and the general public have to go round them in the middle of the road, which has possibly been recently watered. The stand opposite the Café Chicha is perhaps one of the worst cases in point. There is always a policeman on duty at this place, but he does nothing to ameliorate the nuisance, and when complained to it is with the greatest difficulty that one can drive into his head that the cabman is in any way out of order. Personally, I invariably insist on the cab being removed. Sometimes I am met with abuse or stolid resistance, but, being fluent in the language, I finally get my way. Frequently the cabman returns to his former position immediately I have passed, and remains there. It surely would be an easy matter to explain to the policemen, either individually or collectively when on parade, the rights of pedestrians, or simpler still, to put a red paint mark on the footpath indicating the limits of the cabstand. Apologising for troubling you,—I am, etc.,

div.head: REVOLTING CRUELTY AT PORT SAID.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette

Dear Sir,—At the hotels in Egypt collecting cards for the S. P. C. A. are in evidence for support, but at Port Said at least they are not likely to get much as long as the disgusting scenes occur while cattle are being landed. The poor beasts are slung by the feet or horns, kept for hours without water, most likely from the port at which they embark, and on landing try to drink from the sea.

On Tuesday the passengers on a ship in quarantine (therefore unable to take steps) were entertained by the following exhibition of cruelty. A cow ran away from the herd and was chased out on the breakwater by three or four savages, her tail was twisted, she was stoned on the head and body with rocks of about 20 lbs., beaten unmercifully with battens 3 inches thick, sticks were thrust into her anus and vagina, she was thrown off the breakwater into the sea, a fall of 12 feet, dragged over the rocks that cut her hide, hauled up again in a most brutal fashion, her horns torn off and blood was streaming from her nostrils. This performance took about two hours. We are used to seeing acts of cruelty, but not such refined brutality as this. If the S. P. C. A. has a representative, he should be on the spot where these things happen or else he is not much use.—I am, etc.,

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Encore sous l’influence de la liquidation de fin du mois, notre marché a débuté calme et insignifiant On s’attendait même à ce que cet état de marasme durât toute la semaine, lorsque l’heureuse issue des négociations franco-allemandes et la nomination définitive de ministres plénipotentiaires russo-japonais en vue de la paix ont remis à flot les bourses européennes ; ce qui a été d’autant plus facile que le capital abonde en Europe.

A tous ces motifs de hausse est encore venu s’ajouter un facteur important: la reprise soudaine et considérable des cotons à la suite du rapport du Bureau d’Agriculture de Washington sur les prévisions de la prochaine récolte. Sur notre place, pourtant, la spéculation continue à négliger les sociétés nouvelles pour concentrer toute son attention sur les anciennes, dites à tranche dorée. On a pu remarquer cette tendance chez un grand nombre de maisons financières de notre ville qui estiment sans doute que ces valeurs ont été trop dépréciées à l’occasion des derniers lancements de compagnies.

La valeur qui a donné lieu au plus fort mouvement est l’Agricole en raison de l’ouverture de la souscription des nouveaux titres à partir du 10 juillet jusqu’au 2 octobre. Ce fait a de suite attiré des acheteurs. Certains spéculateurs même, pensant que les nouveaux titres ne seraient livrés qu’au 2 octobre, c’est-à dire avec un trimestre de crédit, eurent bientôt fait de les pousser jusqu’à 9 13/16, tandis que l’ancienne émission ne dépassait pas 13 7/8 ; mais, à peine surent-ils que des certificats provisoires au porteur seraient mis en circulation dans un délai maximum d’un mois, qu’ils devinrent plus réservés : la nouvelle émission baissait du coup d’un quart de livre, tandis que l’ancienne avec droit montait de 1/16 à 1/8. L’ancienne avait débuté à 13 9/16 et touché un moment 14 1/16, elle clôture à 1315/16; la nouvelle finit à 9 9/16.
La Fondateur Agricole débute à 912 pour clôturer à 960 acheteurs.

Tout-à-fait calme d’abord à 28, la Daïra monte graduellement jusqu'à 28 1/2, pour réactionner aujourd’hui à 28 3/8. L’assemblée du Crédit Foncier Egyptien réunie au Caire samedi pour la liquidation de la Daïra a décidé, paraît-il, de payer à celle-ci la somme de

6.600.000 outre l'émission de 200,000 actions au courrs de 810 qui, aux termes des statuts du Crédit Foncier, sera d'abord offerte en souscription aux actionnaires du Crédit ; si rémission échoue, auprès des dits actionnaires, la Daïra Sanieh s’engage à les prendre. On ne peut rien dire encore de définitif concernant la liquidation de cette société vu qu'elle a encore diverses affaires à régler.

De 26, au début la National Bank fléchit à 25 29/32 pour reprendre, peu à peu à 26 3/8 par suite de la hausse sur l’Agricole à laquelle la National est, comme on le sait, fort intéressée. La clôture a lieu à ce prix. Comme c’était à prévoir, l’écart entre l’ancienne et la nouvelle émission au profit de cette dernière est tombé de 1/4 à 5,32 de £. On ne tardera pas à voir ce rapprochement s’accentuer et l'ancienne reprendre même le dessus.
La Land Bank ouvre à 9 pour clôturer très ferme et en bonne tendance à 9 3/8.
A 807 à l’ouverture les actions Foncier fléchissent un moment à 805, pour reprendre et clôturer à 817. La part de Fondateur hausse de 7,900 à 8,100.
Délaissée au début à 12 9/16 ex, la Delta Light monte graduellement jusqu’à 12 15/16 en raison d’achats suivis. La clôture s’effectue à 12 7/8.
La Béhéra fléchit de 43 3/4 à 43 pour clôturer à 43 1/4.
La Ramleh Railway fluctue entre 7 et 7 3/16 pour finir offerte à 7 1/16.

De nombreuses transactions ont été effectuées en Tramways d’Alexandrie dont le cours monte de 156 à 158, retombe à 156 par suite d’une concession accordée à une Compagmie d’automobiles sur la route de Ramleh, et reprend ce matin à 158 acheteurs.
La Dividende baisse de 312 à 336 pour finir à 338.
La Salt & Soda a été plutôt délaissée entre 34 et 34/6. La clôture a lieu à 34/3.
De 2 1/4 la Delta Land monte à 2 7/16, prix auquel elle est très demandée.

L’Anglo-American Nile et le groupe des Hôtels ont été en grande faveur durant la semaine écoulée. L’Anglo-American Nile, grâce aux prévisions pour la saison d’hiver qui sont excellentes et à la rumeur d’une entente avec la Hambourg America Linie pour la navigation fluviale, hausse de 5 3/8 à 5 11/16 pour clôturer à 5 19/32.
De 9 au début la Nungovich baisse à 8 15/16 mais reprend d’un bond samedi à 9 5/16. Aujourd'hui la hausse s’accentue à 9 1/2 acheteurs.
Les Upper Egypt Hotels montent également de 4 1/4 à 4 15/32 acheteurs.
Les Egyptian Hotels (Baehler) ouvrent à 2 1/8, détachent coupon et atteignent 2 1/4; ils clôturent à 2 5/16.
Complètement délaissée au début à 27/, la New Egyptian Co hausse rapidement à 35/6 à la nouvelle d’un dividende de 12 %.
La Dividende Menzaleh débute à P.T. 70, atteint 115 et réactionne en clôture à 105. Quant à la Privilégiée, elle est stationnaire à 4 1/8.
L’Investment à fluctué entre 1 1/4 et 1 5/16. On a bien touché ce matin le prix de 1 13/32 mais on est retombé de suite à 1 11/32.
Très soutenu dès l’abord à 1 1/4, le Trust gagne 1/16 et clôture acheteurs à 1 5/16.
De 4/9 les Cotton Mills reprennent à 5/3.
L’Obligation Crédit Foncier ouvre à 317, tombe à 315 1/2, mais remonte en clôture à 319.
La Khédivial Mail tombe sans raison apparente de 4 5/16 à 4 1/8. Les affaires ont d'ailleurs été très clairsemées.
Les Estâtes gagnent 1/16 et remontent de 27/32 à 29/32.

Somme toute, le marché se présente sous un bon aspect et si l’on en finissait avec les complications politiques et l’état troublé de la Russie il se pourrait fort bien que nous eussions une saison d’été aussi animée que l’année dernière, avec cette différence toutefois que le nombre toujours croissant des sociétés nouvelles attâche à notre place un boulet de plus en plus lourd.
Alexandrie, le 10 juillet 1905.
A part la Privilégiée Tramways et le Trust qui ont été poussés la première de 158 1/2 à 161 1/2 et le second de 1 9/32 à 1 3/8, tout-le teste du marché a été complètement négligé ce matin.

Nombre de valeurs sont en réaction : la National Bank fléchit de 26 3/8 à 26 5/16 l’ancienne émission et la nouvelle de 26 1/2 à 26 7/16, l’action Crédit Foncier de 817 à 815, l’Agricole de 13 15/16 à 13 7/8, la Banque d’Athènes de 122 1/2 à 122, la Land Bank de 9 7/16 à 9 3/8, la Daïra de 28 3/4 à 28 1/4, et l’Anglo-American Nile de 5 5/8 à 5 9/16.
Par contre les Markets reprennent de 22 à 22/3, la Sait & Soda de 31/3 à 34/9 avec affaires, et la Ramleh Railway de 7 à 7 1/8.
Les Estates sont stationnaires à 7/8 acheteurs.

div.head: L’Anglo-American Nile
div.p: Nous avons déjà annoncé que la Menzaleh Navigation Cy. inaugurera son service en Octobre prochain entre Port-Saïd et les autres villes du Delta. On sait que cette société a la monopole de la navigation sur le lac Menzaleh qui est pour cette région la voie de communi-cation la plus rapide et la plus économique aussi bien pour le transport des passagers que pour celui des marchandises.

L’Anglo-American administrera moyennant une redevance fixe, la “Menzaleh Cy.’’ de laquelle elle possède un grand nombre d’actions qui viendront dorénavant grossir son dividende qui a été déjà de 9 % l’année dernière.
Un mouvement de hausse sur ces actions est donc probable pour l'hiver prochain.

div.head: Municipalité d’Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS

Il est porté à la connaissance des propriétaires de chiens qu’il pourront retirer ou faire retirer au bureau Sanitaire de la Municipalité, à partir du 12 Juillet courant de 8 h. 1/2 a.m. à midi, le dimanche et jours fériés exceptés, la médaillé que doit porter tout chien circulant sur la voie publique.

Les propriétaires seront tenus d’indiquer très exactement leurs nom, prénoms, nationalité, adresse (rue, propriété, cheikh el Hara, Kism, etc.) ainsi que la race et la couleur du chien, si celui-ci n’est pas présenté à la Municipalité.
La médaille est délivrée gratuitement.
Passé le 10 Août tout chien qui n'en sera pas porteur et qui sera trouvé errant, sera saisi et conduit à la fourrière du Mex.
Alexandrie le 8 Juillet 1905.
L'Administrateur
(signé) W. P. Chataway.

div.head:
RUSSIAN ANARCHY.
THE NAVAL REVOLT.
OFFICIAL VERSION.
div.p: The “Official Messenger,” in a lengthy review of the troubles at Odessa, after dealing with the earlier disturbances on shore, proceeds to relate the history of the naval revolt as follows :—

“The troubles increased and developed into open revolt when a regrettably shameful event occurred, and one without parallel in the annals of the Russian Navy. At four o’clock in the morning of the 28th, there arrived in the harbour of Odessa from Tendrovo Bay a battleship of the Black Sea Squadron, the “Kniaz

temkin,’ which sent ashore its boats with the body of a sailor. The seamen accompanying the body exposed it on the quay, with a note pinned to the chest, declaring that an innocent sailor, named Omelchuk, had been killed by an officer for having expressed dissatisfaction with the food, that all the officers of the battleship had been killed by the crew, and that the battleship would reply by bombarding the town if the authorities of the port caused the body to be removed, or approached the battleship.

“Thousands of workmen assembled on the spot where the body was exposed, and the excitement increased, especially under the influence of incendiary speeches delivered by agitators at the side of the body. The speakers persuaded the crowd to profit by this occurrence to attain the aim indicated by the revolutionaries, but when the Sub-Prefect, with the authorities of the port, arrived on the scene to make an inquiry into the affair, the sailors, with threats and insults, fled.
Story of the Mutiny.

‘According to the evidence of one of the officers and a sailor, who swam by night from the “Kniaz Potemkin” to the land, what took place on the battleship was as follows. The Kniaz Potemkin,” commanded by Commander Golikoff, and accompanied by torpedo-boat No. 267, commanded by Lieut Klodt, left Sebastopol on June 25 for Tendrovo Bay, for firing practice. On the 27th the crew, on the pretext of the bad quality of the meat brought by the torpedo-boat from Odessa, refused to eat the soup. By order of the commander, the crew were assembled on the deck, and the second officer Guiliarovsky, ordered those sailors who did not refuse the food to step forward.

“When the majority of the sailors stepped forward, and the second officer was beginning to write down the names of the minority who remained, the latter seized the rifles which were piled on deck and proceeded to load them. The order to fire on them was not obeyed by the guard, and the second officer, snatching a rifle from one of the guards, fired two or three times on a sailor, and wounded him mortally. The mutinous sailors then fired volleys on the officers, pursuing them to different parts of the ship. The commanding officer was killed, while some officers jumped into the sea, but were fired on and killed in the water, even 47 millimetre guns being used.

“Besides the commanding officer, those killed included the second in command, Guiliarovsky, Lieuts. Neonpakoieff and Toune, Second Lieuts. Grigarieff and Liventzoff, Dr. Smirnoff, and about 30 sailors. The rest of the crew and the crew of the torpedo boat were terrorised by the mutineers, who shelled the torpedo boat, and put under arrest those officers who remained alive.

“On board the battleship a committee of 20 sailors was organised, which took command of the ship and gave orders that she should proceed to Odessa. She arrived there in the evening of the 27th, and next morning sent a boat ashore with the body of the sailor Omelchuk.

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY.
div.p: Writing in the new French weekly review, “L’Energie Française,” the well-known writer M. Cheradame observes that what the Emperor William wants is the abandonment by France of a whole political system which embarrasses Pan-Germanic expansion. It has been plainly intimated to France that in Berlin the right for it to remain neutral is no longer recognised. What is being attempted is to compel France, in the midst of peace, by constant pressure and threat of war, which Germany does not in reality desire, henceforth to play the part of vassal towards the German Empire. That, says M. Cheradame, is the naked truth. The Moroccan affair may be settled for the present, but the development of the tactics revealed by William II. will certainly be repeatedly attempted, and the result will be a period of painful tension, which will last for months and maybe for years. But M. Cheradame points to another danger. He foresees that William II. may offer France a free hand in Morocco in exchange for money to construct the Baghdad Railway, and that that is a possibility which requires vigilance.

He recalls the fact that the railway from Constantinople to the Persian Gulf desired by William 11. has not yet been built owing to want of funds. When, 15 months ago, everything had been settled for a considerable loan in France and the project, for well-known reasons, fell through, the Kaiser was intensely mortified.

div.head: AFTER MANY DAYS.
div.p: It does not frequently happen that recovery of missing jewels so soon follows their disappearence as has been the case in the little adventure at Christie’s last month. The Dowager Duchess of Sutherland, for example, had long to wait before she saw agan the gems stolen from her at a station in Paris. It was a desperately impudent trick of which she was the victim. Just for an instant her maid put down the jewel cafe, and in that instant, “Harry the Valet,” as the thief was called, snatched and made off with them. He did not quite realise the value of his annexation, but roughly smashed with his heel the setting in which the precious trifles were fastened. Upon such as he found safely saleable, he realised ; the bulk of those remaining in his possession came to adorn the person of the young woman who, after sporting her new possessions at the theatre and elsewhere, enabled the police to come up with the thief.

One of the most romantic stories of stolen jewels occurred with Fanny Kemble for heroine. An importunate American danced attendance upon her until one day she finally and peremptorily bade him begone. He gazed steadfastly at her for a moment, then, seeing that she was really in earnest, he flung a packet upon the table. “Well,” he said, “you may at least take this,” and he turned upon his heel and left the room, and she never saw him more. Of course, she opened the package—what woman would not ? In it was a very beautiful jewel, which, as she had not the address of the giver, she had perforce to retain—but not for long. Someone besides herself appreciated its beauty, and took it. Years passed, and she had ceased to repine for its loss. Then she was staying in Italy, and to her at Sorrento there came a pedlar, who, quite by chance, displayed before her his pack of trivial wares. There, among them, its value all unsuspected, lay the long- lost jewel, with nothing to tell how it came into the possession of the hawker.

To match this story one must turn to the experience of a Sussex clergyman. A ring which was an heirloom in his family was stolen from his keeping. Eighteen years passed, and not a word was heard concerning the article. Then it turned up inside one of the fingers of a glove lost at a bazaar in New Zealand. The finder had promoted the bazaar, and was a relative of the owner of the ring, and was the only person on that side of the world who could have identified it. The owner of the glove was one of a number of persons who had in turn possessed the ring. It had passed from hand to hand all round the world, to come, at the Antipodes, to the only person who could stay its farther travels and restore it to the rightful owner.

div.head: THE REVOLT IN YEMEN.
div.p: Dispatches from Yemen state that the rebel Arabs have commenced a siege of Hodeidah, and that the position is critical.

div.head: THE LARGEST NEW BATTLESHIPS.
div.p: The ink is scarcely dry with which was recently recorded the fact that England is about to build the largest, most powerful, and the heaviest-gunned ship which the world has ever seen, and behold ! Japan appears upon the scene, and goes one better—no, three better—with three battleships, each a thousand tons heavier than our own Dreadnought. Two of these are to be built in England, and the third is either begun, or is about to be begun, at Yokosuka Dockyard, in Japan. Nor even yet are we at the limit of displacement, for recent papers announce that Germany is building, with the utmost secrecy, two battleships of 20,000 tons each. The Kaiser is an ambitious man, and it is evident that the fever of bigness is in his veins. It one were to ask for what purpose Germany requires such immense ships, the answer would be obvious. They are for use against England. With regard to our ally, Japan, the case is altogether different. Like Great Britain, Japan is an insular Power, whose safety and existence depend on its power to defend its shores ; and it is not, therefore, surprising to find that even before peace is declared Japan is adding very largely to her Fleet. She has now in course of construction at home and abroad seven warships of the aggregate displacement of 116,350 tons. In addition to these seven ships Japan is also building several medium sized cruisers, small craft, and torpedo boats and torpedo boat destroyers ; so that she will emerge from the present war with a Navy more formidable than that with which she began it.

div.head: SHIPS CARGO OF DYNAMITE, NAPHTHA, AND GASOLINE.
div.p: The most dangerous cargo that ever left New York was that carried by the four-masted schooner Goodwin Stoddard, which sailed recently for San Juan, Porto Rico. She carried five tons of dynamite and several kegs of powder. The deck was loaded with fifty drums of gasoline, containing fifty gallons each, and one hundred barrels of naphtha.
The slightest collision with another vessel would probably mean the utter destruction of the vessels, and the death of every person within a radius of several miles.

Before the ship, which displayed big red flags fore and aft and on all her masts, to warn other vessels of the danger of approaching too near, left New York, her captain called his crew of ten together, and told them that the first man who smoked or struck a match would be instantly thrown overboard
PHILOSOPHY OF TIPS.

The tipping question is ever with us but, apparently, it is still more with the French, who, according to the veracious Dalziel, spend nearly £20,000,000 a year in oiling one another’s palms. It is a big sum, and Chancellors of the Exchequer and charity organisation societies may grieve to see it squandered in this unconsidered fashion. But he would be a bold man who would suggest that tips will ever be abolished, certain recent experiments in that direction notwithstanding. They are one of the many symptoms of an uneasy conscience on the part of a society which requires that men shall labour at tasks not quite worthy of human dignity. It is not, if you think of it, quite worthy of human dignity that a man should spend his life in setting down baked meats on a board for other men to eat ; even the higher development represented in ministering with cabbages at vegetarian feasts leaves something to be desired as the motive of a human career. It is so with the man who daubs your hair with greasy substances, or blacks your boots, or, opens doors for you, touching his cap the while. All these things must be done, but we recognise that they condemn the doer to a monotonous and unfruitful sort of existence. That is why we have invented tips to reconcile men to perform menial offices with an appearance of contentment. That is why, society being what it is, tips will continue to exist, and even to extend, for the tendency of civilisation is to exalt the dignity of man more quickly than to abolish his undignified employments.

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR EXPERIENCE
UTILISED IN NEW BOAT.
div.p: In a description of the Japanese battleship Katori, the launching of which from the yard of Messrs. Vickers, Sons, and Maxim (Limited) will be attended by Prince and Princess Arisugawa, “Engineering” says that in the details there has been utilised to some extent the experience gained in the various actions against the Russian fleet off Port Arthur. As to gun- fire—which is the most important element in a ship of the line—the Katori will mount pairs of 12in. guns in barbettes at the forward and aft end of the upper deck. These are of the Vickers’ type, weighing 57 tons, and they will deliver their 850lb. projectiles with a velocity and energy which will enable them at six miles’ range to perforate armour 9in. in thickness, and at four miles’ range to defeat modern armour about 13in. in thickness.

There are four 10in. guns, mounted singly in barbettes at each corner of the main citadel. The Vickers guns of this type fire a 500lb. shot an energy sufficient to perforate at six miles’ range armour 6 1/2 in. thick, and at four miles’ range 9in. thick. In addition the Katori mounts twelve 6in. guns within a concentrated casemate amidships ; each gun, however, is entirely separated by armour screens. This completes the main armament of the Katori. One round from these twenty main guns represents a collective energy of nearly 375,000 foot-tons.

As the 12in. guns may fire two projectiles per minute, the 10in. guns three rounds, and each 6in. gun ten rounds, the total weight of shot which may be discharged in a minute is 24,8001lbs., representing a collective energy of approximately 1,400,000 foot-tons. All four 12m. guns, may be trained on the broadside. The two 10in. guns and six 6in. guns are similarly utilisable on the broadside, so that one minute’s possible broadside fire is 15,800lb., with a collective energy of over 900,000 foot tons.

As two 12in. guns, two l0in. guns, and two 6in. guns may be fired ahead, the vessel may maintain a very hot pursuit, discharging per minute four projectiles of 850lb., six of 500lb., and twenty of 100lb. For the repelling of torpedo attack there are mounted, in protected positions in various parts of the ship, twelve 12 1/2-pounder, three 3-pounder, and six Maxim guns. Finally the Katori has five submerged tubes for the firing of 18in. torpedoes.

The third element in design has reference to the speed, and in this case the specified rate is 18 1/2 knots, but as the Mikasa very considerably exceeded her designed rate, it would not be surprising if in this case also 19 knots is realised. The total coal capacity is 2,100 tons, which will give the ship a high radius of action.

div.head: THE SIMPLE LIFE.
div.p: Not everybody realises to what good purpose the telephone may be put—not even all-newspaper proprietors. There is a man of whom one knows, a distinguished London correspondent of a great paper on the continent When he was dependent upon the telegraph it cost him on an average £5,000 a year in wires ; for, his messages being urgent, he had to send them at private, not Press rate. And now he lives out in the country. He gets his “Standard” at breakfast, and his “Evening Standard and St. James’s” for lunch ; and such other papers as he needs. Without quitting his home, he furnishes his paper with the latest English opinions and news. A special wire carries his call to London, whence he is put into communication with Paris at given intervals each day. In Paris a stenographer receives the hurried reports, and then transmits them again by telephone to their destination. And so from a country mansion in a Home Counties village the Continent gets its news, not from the English Press. The whole thing, telephone, cost of calls, and everything, comes to less than £500 a year, and the correspondent saves £4,500 per annum, and lives the life of a country squire. Close by is another correspondent who employs the like methods, only he, having indifferent health, telephones his matter to the Continent direct from his bed.

div.head: VICTIMISING ENGLISH GOVERNESSES.
div.p: An adventuress, whose speciality is victimizing English governesses, is being sought by the police of Paris. According to Dalziel, she appears to be a woman of 40 years, dresses stylishly and speaks several languages. One of her favourite methods is to go to a registry office and engage a governess as lady companion, and then to drive away with her ostensibly to her house. On the way, the lady suddenly stops the cab, and sends the governess into a shop for the purpose of making some kind of purchase, with the injuncton to “be quick and come back, and leave your bag or satchel with me.” When the victim returns it is only to find that her new mistress has disappeared, together with the governess’s property.

div.head: LAWYERS AT SEA.
div.p: The following legal conundrum has been raised among Blackburn lawyers : —
An English gentleman with twin sons, born within a few minutes of each other, left a will that his property in Australia should go to whichever of the two sons arrived at the age of 21 first.

The younger of the two emigrated to Australia, and thus, by Australian time, which is some hours in advance of ours, reached the legal age before his elder brother. The lawyers are now wondering which of the two brothers is legally entitled to the property.

div.head: SWEDEN’S RECEPTION.
div.p: A Reuter telegram from Stockholm says the preparations for the reception of Prince and Princess Gustavus Adolphus are being vigorously pushed forward, not only at Stockholm, but also at Malmo and along the whole route which the Royal train will follow on its journey from Malmo to Nynaes. The train will only stop en route at Nassjo, where dinner will be served at 7 o’clock. Flag manufacturers are receiving numerous orders for British flags, the Swedish people desiring that when the young Princess sets foot on Swedish soil the decorations prepared in her honor shall be of an imposing character, with a large display of the colours of her native country.

AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT
New Issue of Shares for Increase of Capital.
div.p: IN PURSUANCE of an Extraordinary General Meeting held on the18th May 1905, the Board of Directors of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt offer 248,000 new shares of the said Bank of Five pounds sterling each. These shares will constitute an increase of the Capital of the Bank, and are issued in conformity with the Statutes at the price of Five Pounds sterling per share, payable on application.
Application should be made:—
in EGYPT to the Head Office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo and to the Branch at Alexandria.
in LONDON to the London Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 & 5, King William Street, E.C.
The new shares will rank for dividend from the 1st January 1906, that is to say from the beginning of next year.
Every shareholder has the right on application to an allotment of one new share in respect of every old share held.

All shareholders who wish to exerqise their rights must under pain of forfeiture of those rights, lodge their applications at one of the places named above on or before the2nd October 1905 depositing their Share Warrants together with the total amount payable, viz : £5 per share.
The President of the Board of Director, (signed) Elwin Palmer.

div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE.15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement dela rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courantà midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.

Alexandrie,le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de réfection des troittoirs dela rue Bab-el-Mellouk.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE.20.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le18 juillet 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour la réfection des troittoirsrue Bab-el-Mellouk.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tardle 18 juilletà midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie,le 6 juillet 1905.

div.head: Notice.
div.p: NOTICE is hereby given to all persons having claims against the estate of the lateMiralai Boulnois Bey, Officer Commanding the Bahr el Ghazal district(Major, Royal Artillery), that such claims must be forwarded endorsed as such to the Assistant Adjutant General, War Office, Cairo, to arrive on or before the7th August, 1905, after which date they will not be taken into consideration.
